aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel module

class aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel.BasisKernel(fixed_indices=None, fixed_vars=None, n_fixed_vars=0, ix_map=None, dict_interactions=None, phi=None, diff_phi=None, psi=None, diff_psi=None, upsilon=None, diff_sim_upsilon=None, diff_cross_upsilon=None, allow_simu=True, sim_func=None, l1_norm=None, diff_l1_norm=None, l2_norm=None, l2_dot=None, l2_distance=None, kl_divergence=None, diff_kl_divergence=None)

Bases: abc.ABC

Abstract class for parametric families of basis kernels.

A basis kernel with parameters \(\vartheta:=(\vartheta_1, \dots, \vartheta_{n_{\textrm{param}}})\) is characterized by a basis function
\[f_{\vartheta}:[0,+\infty) \to [0,+\infty).\]

We assume each parameter \(\vartheta_i\) leaves in a half-open interval \([b_i, +\infty)\).

In our code, we use sums of basis kernels \(\Big(f^{(r)}_{\vartheta^{(r)}}\Big)_{r \in [n_b]}\) to define Kernels \(\phi_{\theta}\) of an MHP, such that for all \(t \geq 0\)
\[\phi_{\theta}(t) := \sum_{r=1}^{n_{\textrm{b}}} f^{(r)}_{\vartheta^{(r)}}(t),\]

where \(\theta\) is the vector of parameters of kernel \(\phi_{\theta}\), obtainend by concatenating the vectors of parameters \(\vartheta^{(r)}\) of each of the \(n_b\) basis kernels.

n_fixed_vars

DESCRIPTION. The default is 0.

Type

int

Notes

To avoid any confusion, we add that the notion of (sums of) basis kernels is different from the notion of (sums of) basis functions discussed in Cartea, Á., Cohen, S. N., and Labyad, S., (November 22, 2021) ‘Gradient-based estimation of linear Hawkes processes with general kernels’. Available at SSRN. In particular, we do not assume that all basis kernels only have one parameter, and are proportional to a function with fixed parameter values. That is, we do not assume that all basis kernels \(f\) satisfy a structure like

\[f_{\vartheta} = \omega g,\]

where \(g\) is some function and \(\vartheta=(\omega)\).

Users can fix arbitrary values for some of the components of the vector of parameters \(\vartheta\) of the basis kernel. When fitting an MHP, fixed parameters will not be optimized. To avoid confusion, we refer to the vector of all parameters (wether fixed or not) as the variables of the basis kernel, and by abuse we refer to the vector of non-fixed parameters as parameters.
abstract get_interactions(is_reverse=False)
get_n_param()

Get the number of non-fixed parameters of the basis kernel.

Returns

Number of parameters.

Return type

int

Notes

Each parametric class of basis kernels is parametrized by a number of variables \(n_{var}\). Users can fix a number \(n_{fixed}\) of these variables, by explicitly specifying the indices of . We refer to the non-fixed variables as parameters of the BasisKernel object. This function outputs the number of parameters, given by \(n_{param} = n_{var}-n_{fixed}\).

abstract get_n_vars()
get_param_bounds()

Get the list of lower bounds of the domain of each parameter of the basis kernel.

Let \(\vartheta:=(\vartheta_1, \dots, \vartheta_{n_{\textrm{param}}})\) denote the parameters of the basis kernel. Each parameter \(\vartheta_i\) lives in a half-open interval \([b_i, +\infty)\). This method returns the vector \((b_1, \dots, b_{n_{\textrm{param}}})\).

Returns

List of lower bounds of the domain of each parameter of the basis kernel.

Return type

list

Notes

By parameters, we mean the non-fixed paramters.

get_param_names()

Get the list of names of the parameters of the basis kernel.

Returns

List of names of the parameters of the basis kernel.

Return type

list

Notes

By parameters, we mean the non-fixed paramters.

abstract get_var_bounds()
abstract get_var_names()
has_omega_param()

Check if this instance of basis kernel has an \(\omega\) parameter, that is, if the basis kernel function \(f\) satisfies a structure like

\[f_{\vartheta} = \omega g_{\varphi}\]

where \(g_{\varphi}\) is some function parametrized by \(\varphi\) and \(\omega\) is a positive parameter. In this case, the parameters of the basis kernel are

\[\vartheta^\intercal=(\omega, \varphi^\intercal).\]

We allow for the vector of parameters \(\varphi^\intercal\) to be empty in this definition.

Returns

True if the basis kernel has an omega type parameter, False otherwise.

Return type

bool

Notes

By parameters, we mean the non-fixed paramters.

make_kernel_functionals()

Set the attributes corresponding to kernel functionals and their derivatives, as functions of (non-fixed) parameters. The functional \(\psi\) is defined for all \(t \geq 0\) by

\[\psi(t) := \int_{[0,t]} f(u)du\]

The functional \(\Upsilon\) is defined for all \(t,s \geq 0\) and for all functions \(\tilde{f}\) by

\[\Upsilon[f, \tilde{f}](t,s) := \int_{[0,t]} f(u)\tilde{f}(u+s)du\]

In our implementation we denote the functions:

  • \(f\) by the attribute phi;

  • \(\frac{\partial f}{\partial \vartheta_p}\) by the attribute diff_phi;

  • \(\psi\) by the attribute psi;

  • \(\frac{\partial \psi}{\partial \vartheta_p}\) by the attribute diff_psi;

  • \(\Upsilon[\cdot, f]\) by the attribute upsilon_rev;

  • \(\Upsilon[f, \cdot]\) by the attribute upsilon;

  • \(\frac{\partial \Upsilon[f, f]}{\partial \vartheta_p}\) by the attribute diff_sim_upsilon;

  • \(\frac{\partial \Upsilon[\cdot, f]}{\partial \vartheta_p}\) by the attribute diff_cross_upsilon_rev;

  • \(\frac{\partial \Upsilon[f, \cdot]}{\partial \vartheta_p}\) by the attribute diff_cross_upsilon;

Raises

NotImplementedError – DESCRIPTION.

Returns

DESCRIPTION.

Return type

TYPE

Notes

See Cartea, Á., Cohen, S. N., and Labyad, S., (November 22, 2021) ‘Gradient-based estimation of linear Hawkes processes with general kernels’. Available at SSRN.

abstract make_kl_divergence(basis_kern_2, vars_1, vars_2)
abstract make_kl_divergence_rev(basis_kern_2, vars_2, vars_1)
make_kl_functionals()

Set the attributes that compute the Kullback–Leibler (KL) divergence and its derivatives as functions of (non-fixed) parameters. Let \(f_{\vartheta}\) denote the basis kernel function with parameters \(\vartheta\). The KL divergence between the basis kernel function \(f_{\vartheta}\) and some other (nonzero) basis kernel function \(g_{\vartheta^\prime}\) is defined by

\[D_{\mathrm{KL}}(f_{\vartheta} \| g_{\vartheta^\prime):=\int_{[0,+\infty]} f_{\vartheta}(x) \log \left(\frac{f_{\vartheta}(x)}{g_{\vartheta^\prime(x)}\right) d x\]

In our implementation we denote the functions:

  • \(\| f_{\vartheta} \|_2\) by the attribute kl_divergence;

  • \(\frac{\partial \)}{partial vartheta_p}` by the attribute diff_kl_divergence.

make_l1_metrics()

Set the function attributes that comupte the \(L_{1}\) norm of the basis kernel \(f\) and its derivatives, as functions of (non-fixed) parameters. The \(L_{1}\) norm of the basis kernel \(f\) is defined by

\[\| f_{\vartheta} \|_1 := \int_{[0,+\infty]} |f_{\vartheta}(u)|du.\]

In our implementation we denote the functions:

  • \(\| f_{\vartheta} \|_1\) by the attribute l1_norm;

  • \(\frac{\partial \)}{partial vartheta_p}` by the attribute diff_l1_norm.

abstract make_l1_norm(vars_)
abstract make_l2_dot(basis_kern_2, vars_1, vars_2)
make_l2_metrics()

Set the function attributes that compute \(L_{2}\) norms, metrics inner-products, and their derivatives as functions of (non-fixed) parameters. Let \(f_{\vartheta}\) denote the basis kernel function with parameters \(\vartheta\). The \(L_{2}\) norm of the basis kernel function \(f_{\vartheta}\) is defined by

\[\| f_{\vartheta} \|_2^2 := \int_{[0,+\infty]} |f_{\vartheta}(u)|^2du.\]

The \(L_{2}\) inner product between the basis kernel function \(f_{\vartheta}\) and some other basis kernel function \(g_{\vartheta^\prime}\) is defined by

\[\langle f,g\rangle_2 := \int_{[0,+\infty]} f_{\vartheta}(u)g_{\vartheta^\prime}(u)du.\]

The \(L_{2}\) metric between \(f_{\vartheta}\) and \(g_{\vartheta^\prime}\) is defined by

\[d_2(f_{\vartheta}, g_{\vartheta^\prime}) := \| f_{\vartheta}-g_{\vartheta^\prime} \|_2.\]

In our implementation we denote the functions:

  • \(\| f_{\vartheta} \|_2\) by the attribute l2_norm;

  • \(\frac{\partial \)}{partial vartheta_p}` by the attribute diff_l2_norm.

abstract make_l2_norm(vars_)
abstract make_phi(t, vars_)
abstract make_psi(t, vars_)

aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel_delayedexp module

class aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel_delayedexp.DelayedExponentialKernel(fixed_indices=None, fixed_vars=None, n_fixed_vars=0, ix_map=None, dict_interactions=None, phi=None, diff_phi=None, psi=None, diff_psi=None, upsilon=None, diff_sim_upsilon=None, diff_cross_upsilon=None, allow_simu=True, sim_func=None, l1_norm=None, diff_l1_norm=None, l2_norm=None, l2_dot=None, l2_distance=None, kl_divergence=None, diff_kl_divergence=None)

Bases: aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel.BasisKernel

Class for delayed exponential basis kernels. The associated basis function is defined for all \(t \geq 0\) by

\[f_{\vartheta}(t) := \omega\beta\exp(-\beta (t-\delta))\mathbb{1}_{t > \delta}.\]

The parameters of this basis kernel are given by

\[\vartheta := (\omega,\beta, \delta).\]

where

  • \(\omega \geq 0\) controls the \(L_{1}\) norm of \(f\);

  • \(\beta > 0\) is the decay rate of \(f\);

  • \(\delta > 0\) is the delay of \(f\).

Notes

The closed form expressions for the derivatives of the functions \(\Phi\), \(\Psi\), and \(\Upsilon\) are available in Cartea, Á., Cohen, S. N., and Labyad, S., (November 22, 2021) ‘Gradient-based estimation of linear Hawkes processes with general kernels’. Available at SSRN.

aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel_exponential module

class aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel_exponential.ExponentialKernel(fixed_indices=None, fixed_vars=None, n_fixed_vars=0, ix_map=None, dict_interactions=None, phi=None, diff_phi=None, psi=None, diff_psi=None, upsilon=None, diff_sim_upsilon=None, diff_cross_upsilon=None, allow_simu=True, sim_func=None, l1_norm=None, diff_l1_norm=None, l2_norm=None, l2_dot=None, l2_distance=None, kl_divergence=None, diff_kl_divergence=None)

Bases: aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel.BasisKernel

Class for exponential basis kernels. The associated basis function is defined for all \(t \geq 0\) by

\[f_{\vartheta}(t) := \omega\beta\exp(-\beta t).\]

The parameters of this basis kernel are given by

\[\vartheta := (\omega,\beta).\]

where

  • \(\omega \geq 0\) controls the \(L_{1}\) norm of \(f\);

  • \(\beta > 0\) is the decay rate of \(f\).

Notes

The closed form expressions for the derivatives of the functions \(\Phi\), \(\Psi\), and \(\Upsilon\) are available in Cartea, Á., Cohen, S. N., and Labyad, S., (November 22, 2021) ‘Gradient-based estimation of linear Hawkes processes with general kernels’. Available at SSRN.

aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel_gaussian module

class aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel_gaussian.GaussianKernel(fixed_indices=None, fixed_vars=None, n_fixed_vars=0, ix_map=None, dict_interactions=None, phi=None, diff_phi=None, psi=None, diff_psi=None, upsilon=None, diff_sim_upsilon=None, diff_cross_upsilon=None, allow_simu=True, sim_func=None, l1_norm=None, diff_l1_norm=None, l2_norm=None, l2_dot=None, l2_distance=None, kl_divergence=None, diff_kl_divergence=None)

Bases: aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel.BasisKernel

Class for Gaussian basis kernels. The associated basis function is defined for all \(t \geq 0\) by

\[f_{\vartheta}(t) := \frac{\omega}{\beta\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp\bigg(-\frac{(t-\delta)^2}{2\beta^2}\bigg).\]

The parameters of this basis kernel are given by

\[\vartheta := (\omega,\beta,\delta).\]

where

  • \(\omega \geq 0\) controls the \(L_{1}\) norm of \(f\);

  • \(\beta > 0\) is the standard deviation of the Gaussian;

  • \(\delta > 0\) is the mean of the Gaussian.

Notes

The closed form expressions for the derivatives of the functions \(\Phi\), \(\Psi\), and \(\Upsilon\) are available in Cartea, Á., Cohen, S. N., and Labyad, S., (November 22, 2021) ‘Gradient-based estimation of linear Hawkes processes with general kernels’. Available at SSRN.

aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel_null module

class aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel_null.NullKernel(fixed_indices=None, fixed_vars=None, n_fixed_vars=0, ix_map=None, dict_interactions=None, phi=None, diff_phi=None, psi=None, diff_psi=None, upsilon=None, diff_sim_upsilon=None, diff_cross_upsilon=None, allow_simu=True, sim_func=None, l1_norm=None, diff_l1_norm=None, l2_norm=None, l2_dot=None, l2_distance=None, kl_divergence=None, diff_kl_divergence=None)

Bases: aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel.BasisKernel

Class for null kernels. The associated basis function is defined for all \(t \geq 0\) by

\[f_{\vartheta}(t) := 0.\]

Notes

The closed form expressions for the derivatives of the functions \(\Phi\), \(\Psi\), and \(\Upsilon\) are available in Cartea, Á., Cohen, S. N., and Labyad, S., (November 22, 2021) ‘Gradient-based estimation of linear Hawkes processes with general kernels’. Available at SSRN.

aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel_rayleigh module

class aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel_rayleigh.RayleighKernel(fixed_indices=None, fixed_vars=None, n_fixed_vars=0, ix_map=None, dict_interactions=None, phi=None, diff_phi=None, psi=None, diff_psi=None, upsilon=None, diff_sim_upsilon=None, diff_cross_upsilon=None, allow_simu=True, sim_func=None, l1_norm=None, diff_l1_norm=None, l2_norm=None, l2_dot=None, l2_distance=None, kl_divergence=None, diff_kl_divergence=None)

Bases: aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel.BasisKernel

Class for Rayleigh basis kernels. The associated basis function is defined for all \(t \geq 0\) by

\[f_{\vartheta}(t) := \omega \frac{t}{\beta^{2}} \exp \left(-\frac{t^{2}}{2 \beta^{2}}\right).\]

The parameters of this basis kernel are given by

\[\vartheta := (\omega, \beta).\]

where

  • \(\omega \geq 0\) controls the \(L_{1}\) norm of \(f\);

  • \(\beta > 0\) is the scale parameter.

Notes

The closed form expressions for the derivatives of the functions \(\Phi\), \(\Psi\), and \(\Upsilon\) are available in Cartea, Á., Cohen, S. N., and Labyad, S., (November 22, 2021) ‘Gradient-based estimation of linear Hawkes processes with general kernels’. Available at SSRN.

aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel_triangle module

class aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel_triangle.TriangularKernel(fixed_indices=None, fixed_vars=None, n_fixed_vars=0, ix_map=None, dict_interactions=None, phi=None, diff_phi=None, psi=None, diff_psi=None, upsilon=None, diff_sim_upsilon=None, diff_cross_upsilon=None, allow_simu=True, sim_func=None, l1_norm=None, diff_l1_norm=None, l2_norm=None, l2_dot=None, l2_distance=None, kl_divergence=None, diff_kl_divergence=None)

Bases: aslsd.basis_kernels.basis_kernel.BasisKernel

Class for triangular basis kernels. The associated basis function is defined for all \(t \geq 0\) by

\[f_{\vartheta}(t) := \omega \left(\frac{t-\alpha}{\beta} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{0 \leq t-\alpha \leq \beta\right\}}-\frac{t-\alpha-\beta-\delta}{\delta} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{0 \leq t-\alpha-\beta \leq \delta\right\}}\right).\]

The parameters of this basis kernel are given by

\[\vartheta := (\omega, \alpha, \beta, \delta).\]

where

  • \(\omega \geq 0\) controls the \(L_{1}\) norm of \(f\);

  • \(\alpha \geq 0\) is the left corner of the triangle;

  • \(\beta \geq 0\) is the distance to the altitude foot;

  • \(\delta \geq 0\) is the distance between the altitude foot and the right corner of the triangle.

Notes

The closed form expressions for the derivatives of the functions \(\Phi\), \(\Psi\), and \(\Upsilon\) are available in Cartea, Á., Cohen, S. N., and Labyad, S., (November 22, 2021) ‘Gradient-based estimation of linear Hawkes processes with general kernels’. Available at SSRN.
